definition: A guard in which the sword is held low in front of the body with the point toward the ground.
A longsword guard with the hilt held high above the head, the blade angling back and upward. An attack “from the Day” is a high downward cut from above.
A guard in which the sword is held to the side of the head, with the point extended toward the opponent’s face – the weapon stands up like an ox’s horn.

A guard with the sword’s hilt held low by the hip (inside or outside the knee) and the point angled upward toward the opponent’s face. In Meyer’s longsword, the left version has the left foot forward (and vice-versa for right).
A guard (used in longsword and dusack) in which the sword is held over the rear shoulder, hanging back in a posture of wrath (anger).
A guard position (in longsword and polearms) with the hands holding the weapon low at the hip on one side, the tip of the blade extended backward and downward away from the opponent.
A guard in which the arms and sword are fully extended forward toward the opponent, so the point is threatened straight at them (the longest reach position).
A guard in longsword where the sword is held horizontally near the base of the chest, point aimed forward at the opponent, with the short (false) edge resting on the inside of the forward arm.

A guard that results from a low cut: the arms are forward with the point of the sword angled upward. It is essentially the end position of a low cut, with the sword extended high (like a unicorn’s horn).

A guard historically similar to Pflug (low forward guard), but Meyer notes that in contemporary use it refers to the Crossed Guard (arms crossed low). In Meyer’s rapier, Iron Gate is like a forward Plow with edges vertical.

The tactical principle of acting “in the instant” – an immediate, simultaneous response that seizes the initiative. Indes denotes an instantaneous timing that gains advantage between the opponent’s motions.
The state of being “before” the opponent – having the initiative. To have the Vor means you are controlling the fight by attacking first, forcing the opponent to respond to your actions.

The state of being “after” – i.e. reacting second. If the opponent has the initiative and you must respond to their attack, you are in the Nach. It implies a defensive or responsive role until you can seize initiative back.

Literally “feeling” the opponent’s blade in the bind – using tactile sensitivity to gauge whether the opponent is soft or hard (weak or strong pressure) on the sword, thereby judging their intent or next move through blade contact.
The initial phase of a fight – when fencers close the distance from their starting guards and initiate an attack. The Zufechten encompasses coming into range and launching the first strike or thrust.

The phase of combat after the initial clash – characterized by close engagement and blade work (winding, binding, etc.). In the Liechtenauer tradition it refers to the “war” of fighting in the bind (Handarbeit), the flurry of attacks and counters once swords have met.

The final phase of an encounter – exiting the fight safely. In Meyer’s usage, the Withdrawal often involves retreating out of range while covering oneself with a final parting cut, to prevent the opponent from pursuing.

The “close work” of the fight once blades are engaged. This refers to the complex actions in the bind (winding, grappling, etc.) – essentially synonymous with the Krieg or middle phase, when fencers work for an opening at short range.

A diagonally downward cut from the shoulder (the archetypal cut from the right shoulder). It is named for striking with wrath or anger. In Meyer’s 1570 treatise it’s also nicknamed the “Father’s Stroke,” being a fundamental blow.

A horizontal cut (notionally flat) delivered with arms high and the short edge leading when thrown from the right (long edge if from the left). The hands are rotated (thumb underneath) so the blade strikes across the target from the side. This cut is often used to strike at the opponent from their open side or to counter high blows.

A cut delivered from above with the sword’s short edge (with arms crossed). In the final position of the strike, the fencer looks askew (“squints”) at the opponent, which gives this cut its name. It is one of the meisterhäue (master strikes) used to break certain guards.

A vertical cut straight down from above, targeting the top of the opponent’s head (as if splitting the scalp or “parting” the hair). This master strike is used to break the Fool’s Guard (Alber) by striking directly down onto the opponent from above.

A cut that comes in at an oblique angle off the line, often with the hands crossed. It’s used to attack or displace from the side (across the line of engagement). In longsword, a typical Krumphau might target the opponent’s hands or weapon by turning the short edge against an incoming strike.

A cut delivered from above (downward strike). In German longsword there are descending cuts from the right or left shoulder; Meyer specifically uses Oberhau for a vertical down cut from high guard. Generally, any strike coming downward from high positions is an Oberhau.

An upward cut swung from below. It is essentially the opposite of an Oberhau, traveling from low to high (often diagonally upward). Unterhauen are rising strikes that can be done from either side (often utilizing the short edge when coming from the left side).

A horizontal cut (traveling through the middle line). This cut is delivered straight across from right to left or vice versa at roughly mid-height. The Zwerchhau is a specialized example of a middle cut performed with unique mechanics.

A parry with opposition that simultaneously threatens the opponent (often described as a counter-thrust). To “set aside,” one extends the sword into Longpoint, turning the long edge against the incoming blow while thrusting at the opponent in one motion.

To “change through” means to slip your blade away and underneath the opponent’s blade to the other side. This is typically done when the opponent goes to parry or thrusts wide, allowing you to evade their weapon and attack an opening on the opposite side.

A follow-up cut made on the other side after a strike is parried or bound. In practice, you strike, and when the opponent parries (binds), you immediately leave your blade engaged and cut around to the opposite side (often with a short-edge cut to the head) without withdrawing – thus “doubling” the attack in the bind.

A technique of quickly withdrawing or pulling your sword back during or after a bind to deceive the opponent and strike elsewhere. By “twitching” the blade out of contact (or out of a line) and then immediately launching a new attack (often a thrust or cut to another opening), you exploit the opponent’s commitment or confusion.

Attacking in the tempo of the opponent’s action – either into the space they leave when they attack or immediately after they miss. Nachreisen means “traveling after”: you follow up on the opponent’s motion (such as a missed cut or when they withdraw) with a strike that lands before they can recover or defend.

Countering a low attack by striking above it with greater reach. To “overrun” an opponent’s low strike (like a low cut or thrust), you throw a high strike at the same time, arms fully extended, so that your blow lands to their upper opening (head/shoulder) before their low attack can reach you.

Closing in for a grapple by literally running or stepping through under the opponent’s weapon. In practice, you duck or pass under their extended arms or blade (often after parrying or when blades are high) to initiate wrestling at the sword (grappling), such as seizing the body or legs.

A slicing action usually done from a bind to wound or control. Literally “slicing off,” it involves sliding or pulling your blade (often the edge) against the opponent while disengaging from the bind. For example, slicing off can target the opponent’s hands or arms as you withdraw your blade, maintaining pressure during the slice.

A close-quarters technique involving grabbing, pinning, or pressing the opponent’s hands (or wrists/weapon hilt). This typically occurs during a grapple (ringen) or when blades are bound, allowing one fencer to physically restrain the opponent’s weapon hand, often to disarm or prevent them from striking.

In Meyer’s schema of attack types, the Provoker is an initial strike intended to provoke the opponent into reacting. Its purpose is to bait the opponent out of their guard or create an opening (for example, a feint or a tentative attack that “provokes” a response).

In Meyer’s system, the Taker is the part of a planned series that “takes” or parries the opponent’s counter-attack. Essentially, after the Provoker incites a response, the Nehmer is the action that safely receives or neutralizes the opponent’s attack (often a parry or displacement), setting up the final blow.

In Meyer’s classification, the Hitter is the final, decisive strike that lands on the opponent. After a Provoker and Taker, the Treffer is the successful blow or thrust that hits the target. Meyer describes the Hitter as the fencer’s own attack that succeeds once the opponent has been drawn out and parried.

A “missing” strike – a deliberate feint or strike that intentionally misses the opponent or their blade. The goal of a Fehler is to draw a reaction or opening from the opponent by appearing to attack one target but then leaving that line (causing the opponent to respond to a threat that isn’t actually there, thus creating an opportunity to hit with a second intention).

Turning or rotating your sword (while in contact with the opponent’s blade) to gain an advantage, usually by threatening a thrust. In the bind, Winden allows you to go from one line to another while keeping pressure – for example, winding your strong edge onto the opponent’s weak to either stab or force their blade aside. (It can also refer to twisting an opponent’s weapon to wrench it free.)

Making first contact with the opponent’s blade (“binding” your sword to theirs). This occurs when your strike is met by the opponent’s blade (or you deliberately place your blade against theirs). The bind creates the opportunity for feeling (Fühlen) and subsequent techniques like winding or mutating. Once blades are bound, both fighters vie for leverage and openings in the bind.
